body:
@Chris2011 update was pushed via update centre. https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/6344fac486525e69369bea981e7c800c3e04c3beb2cfc26d0798deb5%40%3Cdev.netbeans.apache.org%3E  Just remembered Laszlo did similar with 11.0 too.

@lkishalmi Process used in 11.2 and discussed on list was PR to master (use of Cherry Pick label), then once merged a cherry picked PR to release branch - release branch specific testing and review.  See eg. #1604 and #1659  Suggest we follow same for 12.0? Up to @ebarboni if he wants to RM a follow up patch release, or someone else could.  Have added new description to Cherry Pick label and will add to this PR.
this kind of patch after release make all the maven artefacts desync . Would prefer merge for Voting candidate 1

@ebarboni we agreed after 11.1 to have vc identical to last beta, because we didn't there on first vc and it caused major problem and delay. I know at least one thing that will probably require update - Oracle's nb-javac with Java 14.  We're going to need to be able to push updates to 12.0 in the next year - maybe need to work out a way to handle that on Maven side?
ok, maven will need full artefact regeneration 800M thats why we have out of sync maven artefacts for the release with patch.

Yes, I know.  We discussed same with 11.2, and about possible workarounds - something to discuss on dev@.  And reason to maybe batch up and release a patch update as infrequently as possible!  Longer term maybe we need modules to be released under spec version and a BOM for releases?  Shorter term, maybe we can work out a way to just add RELEASE120-1 to changed files?

That's something we should probably discuss intricacies of on dev@. Be good to find a better way to handle updates in Maven, as Matthias' work on update centres has made it more feasible to ship patch updates to releases.

Agreed, this by itself might not be enough to release patch update unless other things make that necessary.

I'm -0 to merging this for vc - your call.

> I will remove all the OmegaT files and keep the generated properties files. What do you think? I am considering to remove all the help files too since it is not used anymore. It will reduce the diff a lot.

I think that would make sense, in my opinion.

> Should I do this just in the dialog or the File > Save Automatically menu item too?

I hadn't noticed that menu item. I don't think it should be there--if every option got its own menu item, the menus would get very long. Just having the settings in the options dialog is good enough. (But regardless, yes, I would always use the word "Autosave" instead of "Save Automatically".)

(So, to your later question, yes, I would suggest removing the menu and toolbar action. But you could still keep the code for it, if you want--just remove the action registration. That way, the user can still drop it in a customized toolbar if they want, or we can use it later if we change our mind.)

> To merge the two tabs, probably I will need to merge both modules. Is it desirable?

I see--perhaps not. I'd go with lkishalmi's opinion here.

@junichi11

So, can we merge it?

@junichi11

Sorry for being an ignorant :)
@tmysik No. NetBeans 12.0 has not been released yet. I'll let you know when we can do that :)
@junichi11 OKOK, merging will be on you :)
@tmysik No problem at all. I appreciate your review :)

@junichi11

I maybe wrote line or two of the PHP support but that would be nothing without your work you do now and the last couple of years!
Great work!
do we have limit on workload / usage for githubactions?

> do we have limit on workload / usage for githubactions?

These are the usage limits: https://help.github.com/en/actions/getting-started-with-github-actions/about-github-actions#usage-limits. Seems that there isn't any limitation in build minutes for open projects.
Hey, what is the state here?

@tmysik Default rules can be combined with custom rules in file - see http://phpmd.org/documentation/index.html
My intention is to make Default Rule Sets optional, so using only custom rule set would be possible.

@KacerCZ 

I am not sure I understand. So - what about adding a checkbox that would enable _Default Rule Sets_ field? Would that work? :thinking:

@KacerCZ 

BTW looking at the attached images, I guess that the _Rule Set File_ textfield should be as long as the other 2 text fields above (it means that both the _Browse..._ buttons would be aligned and after the new one, there would be a free space).

What do you think?

CC @junichi11

I would add an empty string or whitespace to the list if that's possible. Or I would change the label to a checkbox as @tmysik wrote. 

> BTW looking at the attached images, I guess that the Rule Set File textfield should be as long as the other 2 text fields above (it means that both the Browse... buttons would be aligned and after the new one, there would be a free space).

Agree.

> Hey, what is the state here?

+1. Signed documents were sent long ago in January...

Did you hear back from Apache about it? If not, we can find out. 

Once we’re able to do so, we should create a Kotlin branch on our NetBeans GitHub for the contributed Kotlin code.

> Did you hear back from Apache about it? If not, we can find out.

I received only a short e-mail confirming that documents arrived to Apache, nothing else.

That's all that you need, great. The documents have been received, there are no objections, so we can go ahead and create a branch with your code -- do you foresee any problems with it, how solid is it in your opinion?

I'd say that when you are doing something first time, you almost always have some problems. This code will definitely need some attention, see e.g. issues in https://github.com/JetBrains/kotlin-netbeans/issues.

Ok - this won't fly - Actions on PRs can't create comments on themselves. It is even documentated:

https://github.community/t/github-actions-are-severely-limited-on-prs/18179

and ugly work around created:

https://github.com/nyurik/auto_pr_comments_from_forks

Maybe I'll rebuild this as a github app and create an authorized token for this *arg*

@hectorespert I just polished my implementation to put it into production and now learned, that it only worked, because my PRs were created from the same repository (I have a serious WTF moment) - I'll see what can I find as a alternative but at this point my idea is dead in the water.

It is a pity, it looked very good. What about if I change this implementation to do little checks in the email and username? Only to check if this contains any reference to github,  a username with a number or any other little check. We can use it while we find an alternative.

> and ugly work around created:
> 
> https://github.com/nyurik/auto_pr_comments_from_forks

It is an ugly work around, but seems simpler to implement than a GitHub app. On the other hand, a GitHub app is the ideal option.

I guess I was hoping the processing would adjust dynamically (i.e. the processing would switch to file-by-file if it would run out of memory).

Anyway - my proposal is to add an option to enable this and push (after master opens), so that we can test in practice.
By an option, I mean a command line option like -J-Djava.enable.single.javac=true; which can be tested using Boolean.getBoolean("java.enable.single.javac").

@junichi11 I added whitespace to list of built-in rule sets and made sure it does not goes into command parameters.
@tmysik I fixed alignment of Browse button as you suggested.
Same alignment issue is in configuration for PHPStan, shall I prepare PR to fix it?

Options after changes:
![after2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4249184/83572430-dd1b0880-a529-11ea-8d4f-36608dfd2d40.png)

Inspection customization:
![after-customizer](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4249184/83572442-e2785300-a529-11ea-97c2-09251d7b74df.png)
Please review.

**UPDATE:** Now I see that your change is only the empty item in the _Rule Sets_ field, right? I really need to check yout and run your branch, sorry.

The original comment follows:

@KacerCZ 

The last screenshot looks a bit unusually to me, I mean the _Enabled_ checkbox. Try to look at some other dialogs in NetBeans, I would expect more the checkbox directly at _Rule Sets_ label. Or does the checkbox enable te whole form (both _Rule Sets_ as well as _Rule Set File_)?

(Sorry, did not get time to checkout your branch and try it, will try to do it.)

Thank you.

CC @junichi11

@tmysik Yes, I added empty item to list selection of predefined rules. This empty item is ignored when parameters for Mess detector are created.
Valid cases are:
- one or more predefined rule sets and no rule set file
- empty predefined rule set and rule set file
- one or more predefined rule sets and rule set file
Invalid case is when there is no predefined rule selected and also no rule set file is used.

The second screenshot is from inspection customization dialog. 
_Enabled_ checkbox enables running of selected analyzer in given configuration.
1. From main menu select Source > Inspect.
2. In Inspect dialog select Use > Configuration and select Default.
3. Click Manage next to Default. 
4. Select Analyzer > Mess Detector - that is the dialog from screenshot
One quick note - maybe instead of an empty item in the list, we could add something like _<ignored>_ or _<unused>_ or similarly. What do you think?

> One quick note - maybe instead of an empty item in the list, we could add something like _<ignored>_ or _<unused>_ or similarly.

Nice idea :) It's easy to understand, I think.
BTW, I added the `Enabled` checkbox before because all analyzers are run when a user customizes a configuration if the checkbox doesn't exist.
Great!

I replaced empty string with _<none>_ and updated validation.
I added missing listener for rule set file textfield in MessDetectorCustomizerPanel (rule set file was not saved after change).
Shall we also snapshot the 12.0 API in this PR? Relatively related...

I think #2165 is to be merged both on master and release120 branch before this PR can be merged.
This one is intended only for master

@JaroslavTulach not really, because in between the snapshot of API sigs needs a PR / merge across to release120 so the release branch has updated sigs for testing any patch updates.

Edit - comment overlap!
@neilcsmith-net I will cherry pick on release120 branch. If possible I want to keep release120 clean until maven artefacts are rebuilt. Waiting for infra at the moment
@ebarboni sounds good, and your call - shame about Maven issue. As long as this gets in there before anyone has reason for a patch PR against 12.0 I don't see a problem?!
I close it, I'm going to test other approach https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/2168
This PR is highly illogical..
This PR is highly illogical..

I am sorry for the long delay. Hope everyone is ok in crazy days.

> 
> I hadn't noticed that menu item. I don't think it should be there--if every option got its own menu item, the menus would get very long. Just having the settings in the options dialog is good enough. (But regardless, yes, I would always use the word "Autosave" instead of "Save Automatically".)
> 
> (So, to your later question, yes, I would suggest removing the menu and toolbar action. But you could still keep the code for it, if you want--just remove the action registration. That way, the user can still drop it in a customized toolbar if they want, or we can use it later if we change our mind.)

Great idea! I have just pushed this changed.

> 
> > To merge the two tabs, probably I will need to merge both modules. Is it desirable?
>

Agreed too. It can be reviews int he future, not a big deal.


I have a little question. After we push it to the default distro, I wish to build it in a standalone way and include in the 11.X update center. Where can a I find any documentation how to proceed? More specifically to the Plugin Portal.
Well the NBM will be built in 12.1 might be just added to the 12.0 update center, or an other UC. But that's sure you will be able to download it separately.

Enabling Gradle without enabling support for Groovy in the editor doesn't make much sense to me. While I know that Kotlin guys are trying hard to replace Groovy, 95% project build scripts is still in Groovy, I'd bet.

C/C++ support is likely to end up in a `cnd` cluster. That cluster never had a dependency on `java` cluster. The `cnd` functionality is using Ant (for historical reasons, I'd say) - however to do that the basic Ant support had to be moved to an artificially created `extide` cluster. The logic was that Ant is too Java oriented to belong into generic `ide` cluster (mostly editor, version control, etc.).

Gradle is certainly also "too Java oriented". Maybe it belongs next to Ant into `extide`?

Well, unfortunately the Groovy editor do not offer too much help when editing Gradle files. Also it is not an everyday task for most of the users to edit the build files, mostly just to change/add dependencies and that can be done without Groovy. If someone would enable the Groovy cluster, then it would have more editing options, but that's it.

Thank you for mentioning the extide cluster, yes Gradle could belong there. I just was not aware of the existence of that cluster.
@tmysik @junichi11 Please review.

@junichi11 

Thanks a lot! :bow:
@matthiasblaesing I like that approach even less. Can you at least check if it's been explicitly set first?

@neilcsmith-net why? We know, that the maven embedder will not work correctly if the system property is not set. My understanding is, that setting the property has performance implications, but is necessary if used if you are not faced with a static pom.

@matthiasblaesing I'm aware of that, but hardcoding system properties is not good _in principle_ for end users and/or (platform) developers.  Let's assume with any system property, if it's already set someone has a reason.

Better, thanks! :+1:  Although aren't system properties writeable?  Mind you different security check, so maybe not?  Whichever you think best.

```
System.getProperties().putIfAbsent("maven.defaultProjectBuilder.disableGlobalModelCache", "true");
```

Both versions (the get + check for null variant and the putIfAbsent variant). I have no strong feelings either way. It might make a difference if a security manager is active. In that case the get+check variant might trigger less problems. I think that is a theoretical case.
@matthiasblaesing sounds good to me. After you've tested your build are you going to submit a new PR?
@oyarzun @neilcsmith-net @ebarboni could you please have a look?
@matthiasblaesing pulled your branch and rebuilt. Your implementation of the fix works as intended.
@junichi11 Fixed enabling/disabling of File controls. Thank you.
I'd vote for extide cluster over ide cluster for the base Gradle support - AFAIK we don't have build systems in the ide cluster. C/C++ support should be fine with depending on the extide cluster.
@tmysik @junichi11 Please review.
@KacerCZ Thanks!
@matthiasblaesing its works for me.

@matthiasblaesing haven't tested functionality yet, but thanks for the already set check. Seems safe to merge?  And I guess this needs considering as a cherry-pick (+ spec version increment) for a release branch PR too?

I added the spec version bump to the 12.1 commit (this one). Do we have a procedure for point releases? I would reuse the release120 branch (the tag for 12.0 exists, so the branch is IMHO fair game). Are we agreed?
@BradWalker is this clear to merge?

@matthiasblaesing you might not need the spec version update on master, as they've all just been incremented. Patches in the past have been a second PR to the release branch. The spec version in the release branch should be less than in master - eg. `2.138.1` For one example of how done previously consider #1604 and #1659

Ok - short version: Yes in the past the release branch was used to prepare a patch release. For the spec version increment: I'll let it stay in this commit, as autoupdates require spec version increase and at some point in time we might get real nightly builds and then I'd like this to be pulled.

> @BradWalker is this clear to merge?

Hey @matthiasblaesing, it's ready to go.. I rebased to latest master last night..

@KacerCZ 
BTW, You should submit icla because we would like to avoid troubles for the license.
see: https://www.apache.org/licenses/contributor-agreements.html

Then, As this case, if example data(e.g. ruleset.xml, example code) for testing are needed, please attach them to the JIRA as much as possible. Otherwise, each reviewer has to create data from scratch.
Merging - thank you.

Cool feature, but there seem to be a lot of dependencies introduced:

ide/db.dataview/external/SparseBitSet-1.2.jar is not associated with any license file
ide/db.dataview/external/commons-collections4-4.4.jar is not associated with any license file
ide/db.dataview/external/commons-compress-1.20.jar is not associated with any license file
ide/db.dataview/external/commons-csv-1.8.jar is not associated with any license file
ide/db.dataview/external/commons-math3-3.6.1.jar is not associated with any license file
ide/db.dataview/external/ooxml-schemas-1.4.jar is not associated with any license file
ide/db.dataview/external/poi-4.1.2.jar is not associated with any license file
ide/db.dataview/external/poi-ooxml-4.1.2.jar is not associated with any license file
ide/db.dataview/external/xmlbeans-3.1.0.jar is not associated with any license file

Hi @geertjanw, thank you for your comment.

The dependencies that are introduced are used for the creation of the files in the various supported formats (.csv, .tsv, .xls., .xlsx).

Let me elaborate a bit more about each one.

For the creation of the .csv (Comma Separated Values) and the .tsv (Tab Separated Values) the **commons-csv** library is used. Using a library for that task is a good idea because correctly escaping every character may be tricky and libraries such as **commons-csv** lift this burden.

For the creation of the .xls (Excel 97-2003) files the Apache **poi** library is used. However **poi** for some functionality depends on other libraries too. I have tried to include the minimum required dependencies to make it work as intended.

[Dependencies](https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/apache/poi/poi/4.1.2/poi-4.1.2.pom) required by **poi** are:

- commons-collections4
- commons-math3
- SparseBitSet (if I remember correctly it is required for functionality only used in the unit tests)

For the creation of the .xlsx (Excel) files again the Apache **poi** library is used. Additionally in order to write .xlsx it is required the **poi-ooxml**. This dependency has some other [dependencies](https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/apache/poi/poi-ooxml/4.1.2/poi-ooxml-4.1.2.pom):

- poi-ooxml-schemas
- commons-compress

In its turn **poi-ooxml-schemas** has too as a [dependency](https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/apache/poi/poi-ooxml-schemas/4.1.2/poi-ooxml-schemas-4.1.2.pom) the **xmlbeans**.

As I have mentioned I have tried to include the minimum set of required dependencies in order to achieve the required functionality. As you may see in the maven poms I have linked there are also other transitive dependencies that haven't been included.

All the above dependencies are licensed under the Apache license.

Most dependencies are required for the .xls and .xlsx file creation.

So, I guess there are a significant number of dependencies but I think they are essential. What do you think? Do you have any suggestion about how to reduce the number of dependencies?

If adding too many dependencies is a concern maybe we could add only the .csv/.tsv support for now and reexamine the addition of the .xls/.xlsx support in the future?

Thank you.

P.S.: I see there are some issues in travis such as missing license files. I will address them later if this is going to be accepted.

From a content perspective I'm a bit concerned, that we add a whopping 26MB to the netbeans IDE. POI has many features, but maybe there are other options, that can do the same in less code.
